testimony:
Chairperson, the next applicant I intend calling is Sipho Buthelezi, but I ask for the matter to stand down for a short time.  I must still consult with him and just go through his affidavits.  Unfortunately he was not here yesterday.   He phoned my attorney and gave an explanation why he could not be here, but I see he is here today.
	I didn't say that I'm going to call him, I said Paulos Mbatha but I think I'll also call Paulos Mbatha probably later today, so he will still be called.  I ask for a short adjournment.
Well, Mr Strydom, is there any reason why you have not consulted with your client?

Chairperson, I've consulted with all my clients but just to make it more convenient for the Committee, I must go through their statements before they testify, just to get clarity on each and every aspect.
	I would submit that it shortens the proceedings if I can go through with the interpreter before he testifies, just before the witness testifies.  I've used all the other adjournments during lunch breaks to do consultations up till now, but things went a bit quicker today, so I'm in a bit of trouble at this stage so I will ask for a short adjournment.
Have you consulted?  You are now left with Sipho Buthelezi is it?

Mkhize I must inform the Committee is not present.  I don't about his whereabouts, neither does my attorney.  He hasn't been present since the beginning of this session.  He's never been here, he never came.
Okay, is the applicant who said will be dealt with at the close of things?
I indicated at the beginning that he was not present, he never arrived.
So the outstanding ones are Sipho Buthelezi, Mbatha and then Kubeka.
Right, okay.  Have you consulted with Mr Mbatha on the statement?
Yes, on a previous occasion but not today or yesterday, so I would like a short adjournment to consult with him as well.
I've consulted with him on the last occasion, I took his statement.  That was during the course of these hearings but not again.

A request, can the matter stand down for lunch now till 2 o'clock and then I can consult with three of them then I don't need any further time for any consultations after that?  I can consult with the three of them together.

Mr Berger, what we propose doing is to allow Mr Strydom to consult with the three remaining applicants and then we will take the lunch adjournment now and allow him to consult with all of the applicants and then we will resume after lunch, do you have any objection to that?
The time now is about twenty past twelve, should we come back at one thirty?  It would be one hour and ten minutes.
Can I ask until a quarter to two because I'm going to consult with three people.
Okay, very well.  Well if that is the case, what do you colleagues say to that request?

Okay, very well.  Well the Committee recognises the fact that we have probably been starting too early and perhaps finishing somewhat late and that may well have prevented you from consulting with your clients.  We will adjourn a this stage, take lunch and we will come back at quarter to two.

And when we come back, we expect at least you to have consulted with all the remaining witnesses and could you also make enquiries if you can, as to what is happening to Xholiseni Sibongeleni Mkhize or ask your instructing attorney to make enquiries from the other co-applicants as to when last he was seen or what his position is.

Yes, very well.  May I see all the legal representatives in the Committee shortly after this?  We will rise and come back at quarter to two.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION
Mr Buthelezi, what language are you going to speak?
Sorry, I didn't get the middle name.
Sorry, Judge, we're not getting any translation in English.
Mr Buthelezi, you've signed a Form 1, Amnesty Application, on page 182, is that your signature?
This document has been shown to you and translated to you, and you've indicated that there is one mistake which you want to rectify and that is contained in paragraph 11(b), is that correct?

That paragraph deals with orders that were given inter alia it reads
"Orders were given on the 10th and 17th of June 1992."
Is that correct?
When did you move into the hostel for the first time?
Did you attend any meetings in the hostel prior to the 17th of June 1992?
I also want to refer you to the annexure to this Form 1.  You've indicated to me that you will set out the reasons why you went to Boipatong, in your own words, is that correct?

We will deal with that later.  First I want to show you page 185 and 186, that is the request for further particulars and your answers are on page 187, 188 and 189.  Do you confirm the answers given by you?
You've indicated to me that you want to add something to the answer contained under point 2.2?

The question was, with reference to the two groups of attackers
"In which one you were"
And the answer you've given is:
"I cannot remember."

You added to that
"I think Mkhize."
Is that what you wanted to add, Mkhize's group?
Then I want to refer you to your affidavit on page 190 and your signature on page 192.  Is that your signature?
And do you confirm the contents of that affidavit?
According to this affidavit, you arrived at the hostel on the date of the attack.
I arrived on that day of the attack.
Before you moved into Kwamadala hostel, can you just elaborate on what happened in the townships and what motivated you to move to Kwamadala.

What motivated me to move to Kwamadala hostel, I had a quarrel with two young men.  One of them was Doti and the other one was Skosana.
	Doti and Skosana were there at my place of work at Hollywood Inn Nightclub.  They wanted to hit Timothy Stals Mazibuko with a handgrenade.
	I said to them; stop doing what you intend doing.  If you want peace or harmony stop that because you are going to injure this person and all of us will be affected and the other people who know nothing about this.
	They said they wanted to do their job.  I said - I drew my firearm, a 9mm that was in my possession and I told them that after finishing what they wanted to do, I was also going to hit them back.  
	The other said;  then that means the guy was my friend because I was prepared to do whatever on his behalf.  I told them that this person was a customer.  The situation was bad and I couldn't live freely in the township thereafter.  Whenever I'm walking around the township, I would see people looking at me in a funny way, in a strange way but I knew what the cause was ...(intervention)
Just to interrupt you there, this Doti and Skosana, were they members of the ANC?
Yes, they were well-known members of the ANC.
During that period, were you a member of any political party?
Yes, can you take it from there, what then eventually happened and why did you move to Kwamadala?

The month was April in 1992.  Skosana and other young men who were residing in that same area called me Umkgwenbe.  I told them to stop calling me with such a name.  Skosana referred to me - said I was a dog and he wanted to get something to hit me with.  When the other one opened his jacket I saw an AK47.  I ran away.
	They shot at me but they missed me and I went to my place.  I told my brothers and I told them that the situation was tense.  Just because I'd stopped the guys trying to hit Skosana(sic) with the handgrenade and Skosana influenced the other people against me and they told the other people that I was a member of Inkatha Freedom Party. 
	My situation became worse.  On the 16th we couldn't sleep at our respective places because the people were pelting the house with stones.  We woke up.  I took that firearm, that 9mm.  I shot in the air for about five times.  
	The pelting of the stones subsided and my friend Jabulani said to me; it's better for us to leave the place because the people would come and burn us inside the house.  We did as Jabulani was saying.
	I didn't even know that Jabulani was an IFP member.  We went to Jabulani's girlfriend and we spent a night there at her place.  Jabulani told them about the situation.  After that they said we must get into the shack.  They locked us inside the shack, they locked from the outside.
	Jabulani opened the window and tried to talk to them through the window and asked them why were they using a padlock.  They said they that the people should think that there was no-one inside the shack.
	On the 17th we woke up and Jabulani told us to go to a certain place to get better protection.  I asked him: "Where are we going?" and he said: "Lets go to Kwamadala hostel.  I had no alternative but we had to go to Kwamadala hostel.  We went to Kwamadala hostel, it was three of us.
Who was the third person that went with  you and Jabulani?
It was Doctor, the name was Doctor.
Now when you went to the Kwamadala hostel on that morning or during that day, did you know that there will be an attack on Boipatong that night?
Then what happened, how did you become aware that there was going to be an attack?

After we had got into this hostel in one of the rooms that was occupied by the young men from the township, we saw our old friend that used to work with us at Hollywood.  His name was Serame Mokoena.  We had some money, we bought some liquor.  We just wanted to calm down our emotions with this liquor.  As we were sitting there I went to the toilet to relieve myself.  I heard something like a whistle or siren.  I heard sound.  It looked like some people were talking outside, a number of people were talking outside.  I was in the toilet at the time.
	After relieving myself I went out of the toilet.  I enquired as to what was happening, what was this siren for.  Serame said it might happen that something is going to happen, maybe there are people who want to come to attack us because the siren wouldn't just ring for nothing.  He told us to go to the stadium.
	We went to the stadium.  When we arrived at the stadium, as we were coming in Hollie Bajozi was going out of the stadium.  Serame asked him: "Why are you going out so quick, what was happening?".  Hollie Bajozi told Serame this: "We were instructed to go and fetch our weapons."  
	As he was telling us that, Mkhize came and he said: "I told you that this is the day that you've been waiting for, you must go and arm yourselves."  We left.  When I arrived at the house, Doctor gave me a pump-gun.

Doctor gave me the pump-gun.  After giving me this pump-gun there were two pump-guns left.  One was his and one was Jabulani's.   We left for the stadium.
	When we arrived there, Damarra said each and every man must get out.  We went to Serele and we came back again - I beg your pardon, he said, if they can go to Serele and come back and find a man inside the hostel, that man would be killed.  We left for Serele.
	We used ntelezi just before going to that.  We applied that ntelezi on ourselves and we left through the gate.  We were in a hurry.
Did you know at that stage what was going to happen in Boipatong?
Yes, it was well-known that the Self Defence Units were to be attacked.
Did you agree with the idea that Self Defence Units should be attacked?

No, I did not agree.  As I was going there I did not agree with the idea.  As they said we were going to - if they said that we were going to Zone 12 at Sebokeng, I would be in the forefront but unfortunately we went to this nearest house.
	We went there, we went under the bridge, we walked behind the nursery ...(intervention)
Whilst you are in that area, did you see any Casspir vehicles there and did you get into a Casspir vehicle and were you transported to Boipatong?
So you said you were by foot, what happened then?

We went past the bridge that was on the tar road.  We walked through another footpath through the bridge and we took cover under a big tree.  We were told to wait there for the others.  They came.
	We were divided into two groups and we were told that another group should go in front and the other one would follow.
	In that process we saw a fence from the school that was used to barricade, to close the road, and it was tied up next to a certain pole.  We removed that fence, we went through.  When we were at the corner, at the road that was used by the taxis, we were told to start with the job.
Do you remember who told you that?
I was with Serame and I asked him who was the gentleman that was talking.  He said to me the gentleman was Damarra.  I said fine.
And what job are you referring to?

The job of attacking.  As we were going through on that road, we met with the Self Defence Units at the corner.  Damarra started shooting and the others followed those who had firearms.
	The Self Defence Units shot back.  Damarra took another direction with his group, going towards the direction of the shops.  I took another direction, taking that same street as we had used as we were coming in.  
	I participated, I also shot at the Self Defence Units.  After shooting I left.  I shot pointing at the houses, directing at the houses.
Did you shoot any person in Boipatong?
Did you see if anybody got killed in Boipatong?
I did not get into the houses, I was just walking in the streets.
Did you see if anyone of the attackers stole goods in Boipatong?
After the attack, what happened to your shotgun?

Damarra instructed me to give him the firearms.  He was about to hide them.  I asked Serame why is, this gentleman who wants my firearm, where does he say and Serame said this person is also living in that same yard.  I gave him my firearm.
The following day, were you at the hostel?
At that time did you know Themba Khosa?
Yes, I knew him as I used to see him on TV.
Did you see him there on the following day?  That's now the day after the attack.
Did you hear him issuing a warning that certain bloody clothes should be burnt?
Did you see that some of the goods that were stolen in Boipatong got burnt?
Will you please repeat your question, Sir?
Did you see that stolen goods were burnt?
No, I did not see that.
Yes, I know him very well.
Did he share a room with you in the hostel?
Now when you started living in the hostel on the 17th of June 1992, was Mr Nosenga there already or not?
When did he come to the hostel, according to you?
He came after the Boipatong incident.
Yes, I am certain about that.
Apart from him, can you remember the names of other people that also shared that room?
Yes, I can still remember them.
Can you give the names of the other people?
Hollie Bajosi was a State witness at the trial, is that right?
Is that all the names you can remember?
Yes, for now those are the only names that I can remember.
Before Mr Nosenga moved into the hostel, did you know him?
When were you arrested for this Boipatong incident?
If I'm not mistaken I think it was on the 25th of September 1992.
Do you remember the policeman who came here by the name of Peens?
I just saw them for the very first time on Friday.
Do you know a policeman by the name of Shaka?
Where do you know Shaka from?
I used to see him at Tekani's garage.
Whilst you were moving through Boipatong and whilst you were busy with the attack, did you see any police or military vehicles in Boipatong?
No, I did not see any military vehicles or police vehicles.
During the course of that night of the attack, did you see any vehicles at any stage?

Thank you, Chairperson, I have no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR STRYDOM

I have no questions, thank you, Chairperson.
NO QUESTIONS BY MS PRETORIUS

I have no questions, Mr Chairman.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR DA SILVA
When you arrived at the hostel, who allocated you a room?
If I'm not mistaken I think it was Mr Mthembu.
Were you presented to any committee upon your arrival?
Were you questioned about your political affiliations when you arrived at the hostel?
Will you please repeat the question, M'am.
Were you questioned by anyone about your political affiliations when you arrived at the hostel?
You were simply given a room and invited into the hostel without any questioning or any interrogation?
I remember when we arrived at the gate, Jabulani issued his card, his membership card, IFP membership card.  I think Mr Mthembu asked us something ...(intervention)
What time about did you hear the siren?
Was it the early evening or the late evening?
I think the time was about nine.
When you arrived at the stadium, was anybody speaking to you, were there any speeches being made?
When you arrived at the stadium, did you notice any weapons lying on the floor or anywhere, to be taken by the hostel residents?
Was the pump-gun that you used that night, did that belong to you or did you bring that with Jabulani to the hostel that afternoon?
It was brought by Jabulani in the evening and he said he was giving it to me, it would be mine thereafter.
And as you entered the hostel, did they not search you or anything?  Did they not try to search for weapons or something?

These three pump-guns, Jabulani left with a guy who was, they left with a guy in a car and they went to fetch them in the hostel.  I asked him where did he get the pump-guns, he told me that he had bought the pump-guns from the Sebokeng hostel.
How many people would you say attacked Boipatong that night?
Are you talking about the residents of Kwamadala hostel or the people who were attacked?
No, the Kwamadala hostel, the attackers.
Did you notice anyone wearing a balaclava on their face or covering their face in any manner that night?
Did you notice any white people participating in the attack?
Can you remember when about did Nosenga join the hostel after the attack?
I cannot remember whether he came after weeks or after a month, I just cannot remember.
Well when he arrived, was he only able to speak Sotho?
He came to us and he was speaking in Sotho.
So how did you communicate with him?

I asked him about his visit, why was he there.  He first said to me the people want to burn him in the township because they said he was an IFP member.  I asked him what is it that he did that made the people to say that he was an IFP member ...(intervention)
Mr Buthelezi, that's not really the question, the question is you say that Nosenga spoke Sotho.

Now what you've been asked is how did you communicate with Mr Nosenga.
	Is that the question, M'am?
Yes, I understand the question.  He first greeted us, he said ...(Sotho).  That means he was greeting us in Sotho.  I noticed that he was a Sotho-speaking person.
But my question was, in what language did you communicate with him, how did you talk to him?
I can say I was born here in this Vaal Triangle.  I can speak both languages, Sotho and Zulu.
So were you conversing with him in Sotho?
What was he relating to you, his reasons for joining the hostel?  You were telling us beforehand what he was telling you, can you just tell us again?

When I asked him why he was out of the township, he said the people were saying that he was an IFP member ...(end of tape) washing Hollie Bajosi's car.  I don't know what is it that he told the other gentlemen.
	After a few days I heard Joseph Radebe who was also a witness during the trial, though he did not go to Pretoria, he told me that this person said he was sent by the ANC to try and inspect the place as to where can he plant the bombs.
	I got a shock because I realised that we were staying with someone who wanted to kill us.  I asked him;  gentleman, I asked you yesterday your reasons for being here in this hostel.  He said no, I was afraid, I was too scared.  Then Nosenga was then to be taken to the conference.
Are you telling this Committee that he admitted to you that he was an ANC spy sent to plant bombs in the hostel?
I was not alone, he admitted, I was with the other people.
Did you discuss the attack with Mr Nosenga when he joined the hostel?  Did you relate details of the event of the attack to him?
Joseph Radebe would make an example about someone else in front of him.  I think this is where he got some idea.
What motive would you then give to Mr Nosenga for alleging that he participated in the attack if he did not participate in the attack?
The motive behind him saying that he was one of the people who participated in this Boipatong incident, perhaps he was regarding himself as a journalist, I don't know, or a newsman, I don't know.

Now you've heard the version of Mr Nosenga that I've placed to all your fellow applicants to day, from the meetings that took place leading up to the attack and the attack itself.  I don't want to waste this Committee's time any further, so I'm just going to put to you that that is Nosenga's version, that there were policemen at the time assisting in the attack at Boipatong and that he did participate in the attack at Boipatong.  What are your comments and your comments regarding his statement?

Well I put it to you, insofar as your version contradicts and differs Nosenga's that he is telling the truth and that you are not completely honest and open with this Committee, what are your comments?
I'm the one who is telling the truth.

I have no further questions, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS TANZER

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Buthelezi, after you became aware of Mr Nosenga's statement that he was an ANC spy and that he had been sent by the ANC to come and plant bombs in the hostel, what steps were taken to isolate Mr Nosenga?
What do you mean, isolate him?
Well, were any steps taken against Mr Nosenga?
What steps were taken were that he was taken to Ulundi.
How long after the allegation that he was an ANC spy was it until he was taken to Ulundi?
Yes, I did get the question, I'm still thinking.  No, I do not remember.
Well, was it a week, two weeks, a month?
No, I cannot even begin to estimate.

This was shocking news wasn't it, for you to discover that the man who is sleeping in your room is an ANC spy who has come to kill you, and you can't tell the Committee whether he continued to sleep in your room for a week or for a month after you became aware of that allegation.
He was always under our watchful eyes, even though he went to the toilet at night.
And then how did you become aware of the fact that he was being taken to Ulundi?
A meeting was convened at Kwamadala to the effect that on a particular day people would be going to a conference at Ulundi.
I cannot recall.  I was not quite familiar with the community at the hostel, only a few people.
That was a meeting attended by all the residents of the hostel, is that right?
And at that meeting it was announced that Mr Nosenga is to be taken to the conference in Ulundi?
Was Mr Nosenga at that meeting?
So one can assume then that the entire hostel knew about Mr Nosenga and knew about his confession to be an ANC spy.
And nobody attempted to harm Mr Nosenga in any way, is that right?
Yes, that is correct, we received an instruction to the effect that we should not harm him.
This came from Mr Thembankosi Khumalo.
Was that also at a meeting held in the hostel immediately after it became known that Mr Nosenga was an ANC spy?
Would you please repeat the question, Sir?
This instruction from Mr Khumalo, was it issued at a general meeting in the hostel immediately after it became known that Mr Nosenga was an ANC spy?
Do you know who went to Ulundi with Mr Nosenga?
Yes, there were people with whom I shared a room who went to Ulundi.
Joseph Radebe, Serame Mokoena and Papie Skumbuzo.  In my room I think it was myself and a few others or should I say two boys who were twins.
So Joseph Radebe, Serame Mokoena and papie Skumbuzo, they went to Ulundi?
And when they came back from Ulundi, did they tell you what happened there?
No, they just informed me that Nosenga was put on stage, introduced and he was made to explain what drove him to Kwamadala.
He was put on stage at the national conference and made to explain himself?
Was this in front of the top leadership of the IFP?
And did they tell you what Mr Nosenga said when he was on stage?

They just informed me that Nosenga told the people there that he had been sent by the ANC to infiltrate the hostel and reconnoitre the area to establish where he could plant the bombs.
	I cannot remember which old man asked him but I think he was asked by an old man as to whether he was still prepared to go back to the ANC, and Nosenga is said to have said no, he's a member of Inkatha.
And then what decision - were you informed as to what decision had been taken at conference as to what to do with Mr Nosenga?
Well did Mr Nosenga come back to stay in your room?
Did you speak to him about his trip to Ulundi?
I asked him in the presence of other how they fared to and fro and he told me that they fared well.
Did Mr Nosenga tell you that he had met Chief Mangasotho Buthelezi at the conference?
No, he didn't explain that to me.
So as far as you were concerned it was alright for Mr Nosenga to come back and stay in your room, you were quite happy with that?
Yes, because we had realised that he's a nice person.  He didn't have to be on his own thinking all the time.
So from then on you treated him as a friend?

Mr Buthelezi, I want to put it to you that this version of Mr Nosenga admitting that he was an ANC spy who had come to blow up the hostel and kill the hostel residents is a fabrication and it has been concocted by you and some of your fellow applicants who have recently given evidence.
No, we have witnesses who arrived in Nosenga's presence.  There are people who can testify in my favour in this regard, people who are no longer at the hostel.
Xhala, or should I say the first one would be Tsalmo, Nomjali Fasibiya ...(intervention)
Do you know where he stays?
I used to see him at Zone 7.
When last did you see him?
Tzwee is one person who has the full knowledge to this effect.
No, you said that you last saw Tsalmo at Zone 7.
Ja, but which township, in Boipatong, in Sebokeng or ..."
You said this was last week?
Ja, I've got Salmo, Tzwee, Bajosi, who is the other one?
And where does he stay, Nomjali Fasibiya?
When I asked him last week where he stays, he told me that he stays at the two rooms near Palm Springs.
Yes, and Bajosi, where is he?
At his parents' home, Zone 7, Sebokeng.

Thank you, Chairperson.
	You say that Mr Bajosi would be able to come and tell the Committee everything about Mr Nosenga?
Yes, I trust that he can come here.
Joseph Radebe, is he still alive?
The last time I heard he was in Groenpunt, Groenpunt in Stoffberg.
I have no idea as to whether he is still alive or not.  The last time I heard of him he had gone to Parys.
He too is incarcerated in Sun City.
He cannot be found, he is moving about.
This quarrel that you had with Doti and Skosana was in Sebokeng, am I right?
Were you friendly with Stals Mazibuko at Kwamadala?
Did you see him at Kwamadala?
Did you take your 9mm with you to Kwamadala?
No, we gave it to a boy called Lucky from Everton.
Did you think you wouldn't need your gun once you got to Kwamadala?
Yes, it never occurred to me that I might need it.
So when you went to Kwamadala, you, Doctor and Jabulani, none of you had guns, is that right?
I would say as far as I'm concerned, Doctor and Jabulani had knowledge about the pump-guns.
No, I'm not asking about their knowledge, I'm saying when the three of you entered Kwamadala on the 17th of June 1992, all three of you were unarmed.
And where is Jabulani and Doctor today?
Is it correct that you - or let me ask you this, what time did you enter Kwamadala hostel on the 17th of June?
Wasn't it  about 3 o'clock in the afternoon?
That is my estimation, 12 to 1 is my estimation.
At the criminal trial, page 3444 you said you arrived at the hostel at about 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
I was not sure because - I am saying that I was not sure because I was angry about what happened to me.
So?  Because you were angry you said you arrived at the hostel at 3 o'clock in the afternoon?
That was an estimation of time.
After you got into the hostel you were allocated a room you say, by Mr Mthembu?
And then you went to your room together with Jabulani and Doctor, is that correct?
What did you do between the time you got to your room and the time you heard the siren go off?
We held hands and spoke to some of the gentlemen that we found there.  We bought liquor, we sat drinking.
And there was no talk that afternoon about an attack on Boipatong, was there?
In fact the first indication that you had that something was going on was when you heard the siren?
I asked what this whistle was all about, Serame then told me that we were wanted at the stadium, something might happen.
And Doctor and Jabulani were drinking with you and talking throughout the afternoon?
We sat drinking all together to the time that we heard the siren.
Well you see, my problem with that is there would then be no time for Doctor and Jabulani to go and fetch the shotguns from Sebokeng hostel.
There was time because at some point Jabulani disappeared.
No, you see you said you sat drinking with them the whole afternoon until the siren went off.
Yes, that is what I've just said.
But you also say at some point in the afternoon Jabulani got up and left.
And he left the hostel and he went to Sebokeng hostel, am I right?
I only heard from him when he came back telling me that he was coming back from Sebokeng hostel.
And the distance from Kwamadala to Sebokeng hostel is quite far, am I right?
Yes, that is quite a distance.
And he returned with two shotguns?
I beg your pardon, three shotguns.
By himself he fetched three shotguns and brought them back to Kwamadala.
Despite the fact that he too had no knowledge of any planned attack that night, that correct?
Are you being honest when you say that you only came to the hostel on the 17th of June and that you had no knowledge whatsoever about a prior attack on Boipatong?
Yes, I am telling the truth.
Now when you got to the stadium you had no idea what it was all about, am I right?
What exactly were you told at the stadium?

When we arrived at the entrance point, myself and Serame, that is the entrance point to the arena, we came across Bajosi and we asked him what was happening.  Hollie Bajozi then said to Serame;  Mkhize said this is the time, the time which you all have been waiting for, that we should go and attack.  He then said Mkhize had just said that we should go and fetch our weapons.  Indeed, we went to fetch our weapons.  As we were talking there, Mkhize spoke as well.
Mkhize then said that the day of reckoning has arrived, it's about time we launched the attack.  We then went for our firearms or our weapons.
Did Mr Mkhize say anything else?
I only heard him say what I've just said.  I don't know what he said before we arrived at the Arena.
Did he say who you were going to attack?
